body: @rkeithhill Is this still happening? I wonder if @daxian-dbw might have already fixed it in work he did earlier in the year

Yes, it is still happening.  I'm running PS Core 6.1.0 on WSL (Ubuntu 16.04) on Windows 10 1809:
```
1:115ms> gmo PSReadLine -list -all


    Directory: /home/hillr/.local/share/powershell/Modules


ModuleType Version    Name                                PSEdition ExportedCommands
---------- -------    ----                                --------- ----------------
Script     2.0.0      PSReadLine                          Desk      {Get-PSReadLineKeyHandler, Set-PSReadLineKeyHand...
Script     0.0        PSReadLine                          Desk      {Get-PSReadLineKeyHandler, Get-PSReadLineOption,...
Script     2.0.0      PSReadLine                          Desk      {Get-PSReadLineKeyHandler, Set-PSReadLineKeyHand...
Script     0.0        PSReadLine                          Desk      PSConsoleHostReadLine


    Directory: /usr/local/share/powershell/Modules


ModuleType Version    Name                                PSEdition ExportedCommands
---------- -------    ----                                --------- ----------------
Script     2.0.0      PSReadLine                          Desk      {Get-PSReadLineKeyHandler, Set-PSReadLineKeyHand...
Script     0.0        PSReadLine                          Desk      PSConsoleHostReadLine


    Directory: /opt/microsoft/powershell/6/Modules


ModuleType Version    Name                                PSEdition ExportedCommands
---------- -------    ----                                --------- ----------------
Script     2.0.0      PSReadLine                          Desk      {Get-PSReadLineKeyHandler, Set-PSReadLineKeyHand...
Script     0.0        PSReadLine                          Desk      PSConsoleHostReadLine
```

This happens for me as well, 5.1 and 6.x.  From looking at all properties, it seems to be the RootModule property.

One entry will just have the filename and the other would have the full path.  All other properties match.  It also shows included DLLs, like EPPlus which is included with ImportExcel but not it's own listed module.  It same Module Base but the module name shows as EPPlus.

E.g. RootModule values for a duplicate entry.
ImportExcel.psm1
C:\Users\%UserName%\Documents\WindowsPowerShell\Modules\ImportExcel\6.2.3\ImportExcel.psd1

I'm not seeing this in preview.5 -- has it been fixed recently?
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/32407840/69277297-0c7daf80-0bae-11ea-8637-3598c59a0b6e.png)

Didn't realise this was originally for `gmo -list -all`. The behaviour @vexx32 looks about right to me, although I've discussed with @daxian-dbw before and it wasn't entirely clear to us what `-All` is really supposed to do or why; it blindly recursively searches for things with a module extension. I suspect the duplicate might have been a directory vs module file phenomenon (`PSReadLine/PSReadLine.psm1`, `PSReadLine/PSReadLine.psd1`, `PSReadLine.psm1`, `PSReadLine.psd1`).

Every time `-All` has come up, there's been disagreement about what it's supposed to do and what its use case is, so we try not to touch it (and I'm not sure there are many tests around it). But its implementation is interleaved with `gmo -List`, so it might have been changed unintentionally.

@vexx32, does "http://user-images.githubusercontent.com/32407840/69277297-0c7daf80-0bae-11ea-8637-3598c59a0b6e.png" not depict the problem?

(Additionally, paste output as text if possible, encapsulated by "```". It assists people with slow connections to the internet, and allows quotation to be easy rather than difficult.)

`gmo -list -all` search recursively into all directories in the module path, and try to find all files with a valid PS module extension and return them as `PSModuleInfo` objects.

I believe the scenario for it is to discover nested modules files within the available modules. One example is `PSDesiredStateConfiguration`, an in-box module under `System32` folder. It contains many DSC resources in sub-folders of the `PSDesiredStateConfiguration` directory, and many of them are `.psm1` module files, so you can find them by running the following:
```
PS:2> gmo *Resource -ListAvailable -All

    Directory: C:\program files\powershell\7\Modules

ModuleType Version    PreRelease Name                                PSEdition ExportedCommands
---------- -------    ---------- ----                                --------- ----------------
Manifest   0.0                   PSGet.Resource                      Desk

    Directory: C:\Program Files\WindowsPowerShell\Modules

ModuleType Version    PreRelease Name                                PSEdition ExportedCommands
---------- -------    ---------- ----                                --------- ----------------
Manifest   0.0                   PSGet.Resource                      Desk

    Directory: C:\WINDOWS\system32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\Modules\PSDesiredStateConfiguration\DSCResources

ModuleType Version    PreRelease Name                                PSEdition ExportedCommands
---------- -------    ---------- ----                                --------- ----------------
Script     0.0                   MSFT_ArchiveResource                Desk      {Mount-NetworkPath, Open-ZipFile, Assert-ValidStandardArgs, Trace-Mes…
Script     0.0                   MSFT_EnvironmentResource            Desk      {GetItemProperty, Set-EnvVar, Set-TargetResource, FindPath…}
Script     0.0                   MSFT_GroupResource                  Desk      {Test-TargetResource, IsLocalMachine, Parse-Scope, Set-TargetResource…
Script     0.0                   MSFT_PackageResource                Desk      {Get-MsiProductEntry, Trace-Message, Set-TargetResource, Throw-Termin…
Script     0.0                   MSFT_ProcessResource                Desk      {AssertAbsolutePath, GetWin32ProcessOwner, IsRunFromLocalSystemUser, …
Script     0.0                   MSFT_RegistryResource               Desk      {IsValidRegistryRoot, Get-TargetResourceInternal, ConvertByteArrayToH…
Script     0.0                   MSFT_RoleResource                   Desk      {Test-TargetResource, ValidatePrerequisites, Get-TargetResource, Set-…
Script     0.0                   MSFT_ScriptResource                 Desk      {CheckDeviceGuardStatus, Set-TargetResource, ScriptExecutionHelper, G…
Script     0.0                   MSFT_ServiceResource                Desk      {StartService, NormalizeStartupType, TestStartupType, StopService…}
Script     0.0                   MSFT_UserResource                   Desk      {Set-TargetResourceOnFullSKU, Test-TargetResourceOnFullSKU, Set-Targe…

    Directory: C:\WINDOWS\system32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\Modules

ModuleType Version    PreRelease Name                                PSEdition ExportedCommands
---------- -------    ---------- ----                                --------- ----------------
Manifest   0.0                   PnpDevice.Resource                  Desk
```

The `-All` parameter is not for searching a regular PowerShell module scenario, and `gmo PSReadLine -list` can already return all installed `PSReadLine` modules under the module paths. [The doc](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/microsoft.powershell.core/get-module?view=powershell-7.2#parameters) for this parameter is clear on its behavior in my opinion, and I think we can close this one as by-design.
This issue has been marked as by-design and has not had any activity for **1 day**. It has been closed for housekeeping purposes.
